details.title: COVID-19 UPDATES FROM OCTOBER 29
details.content:
Delhi witnesses steep rise in coronavirus cases after 5,739 test positive in one day and more COVID-19 updates from across India.
(CLICK HERE FOR OCT 29 UPDATES)

details.title: Water sports begin at Srinagar's Dal Lake maintaining COVID-19 safety norms
details.content:
J&K: Water sports activities have resumed at Dal Lake in Srinagar after they were halted amid #COVID19 pandemic. A local, Nasir says, "As far as water sports at Dal Lake is concerned, it attracts immense youth engagement. It also attracts tourists. This is a welcome step." pic.twitter.com/kugw1PKSwD

— ANI (@ANI) October 29, 2020

details.title: COVID-19 recovery rate in Kerala lowest among worst-hit states
details.content:
• Kerala has one of the lowest recovery rates among the 10 worst-hit states.
  • Though daily recoveries have now started exceeding the daily new cases, the experts say the days ahead are going to be a real challenge for the state as the health workers are over-stretched and the hospital beds are almost full with Covid patients

(READ FULL DETAILS HERE)

details.title: Global update | US reaches record 91,295 coronavirus cases in 24 hours
details.content:
#UPDATE Record number of new #coronavirus cases in 24 hours recorded in the US for the first time, Johns Hopkins University tally says.

Within the same 24-hour period, 1,021 people died from Covid-19 in the US, bringing the country's total to 228,625 fatalities

???? Alex Edelman pic.twitter.com/cBehj6YJrh

— AFP news agency (@AFP) October 30, 2020

details.title: Study finds oral polio vaccine may be protecting young Indians from COVID-19
details.content:
A new study has cited genomic evidence to propose that the oral polio vaccine might be protecting young Indians from Covid-19 through a process called cross-protection. 
(READ FULL STUDY HERE)

details.title: India's high testing rate led to falling positivity rate: Centre
details.content:
India has exponentially scaled up its testing capacity from one in January to more than 10.65 cr at present. The very high testing has resulted in the continuously falling positivity rate. It is 7.54% presently: Ministry of Health pic.twitter.com/KpZlyhVxBZ

— ANI (@ANI) October 30, 2020

details.title: Festival season sets in, fear of surge of COVID-19 cases in Karnataka up
details.content:
Government and private hospitals in the city are seeing patients with a history of visiting markets for festive shopping. However, the authorities maintain that it is too early to say if there has been an increase in Covid cases.
(READ FULL REPORT HERE)

Total 10,77,28,088 samples tested for #COVID19 up to 29th October. Of these 11,64,648 samples were tested yesterday: Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) pic.twitter.com/raCvZ7hAt3

— ANI (@ANI) October 30, 2020

details.content:

details.content:

details.title: Active infections fall below six-lakh mark; caseload nears 81 lakh with 48,648 new cases
details.content:
India saw 48,648 new coronavirus infections being reported in a day taking the COVID-19 caseload to 80,88,851, while active cases fell below 6,00,000 and the national recovery rate crossed 91 per cent, according to the Union Health Ministry data updated on Friday
(READ FULL REPORT HERE)

details.title: IN PIC | For Diwali, with precautions!
details.content: Blind Relief Association staff and workers making candles for the upcoming Diwali festival, in New Delhi. (Photo | PTI)

details.title: Odisha | AIIMS Bhubaneswar OPD services to reopen from November 2
details.content:
The OPD was closed from July 10 due to COVID pandemic except for day-care services, radiotherapy, dialysis, trauma and the emergency and lifesaving surgery and IPD services.
(READ FULL REPORT HERE)

details.title: Despite vaccine progress, normalcy likely by end of 2021: US COVID-19 expert Dr Anthony Fauci
details.content:
'If we get a vaccination campaign, and by the second or third quarter of 2021 we have vaccinated a substantial proportion of the people, I think it will be easily by the end of 2021, and perhaps even into the next year, before we start having some semblances of normality,' Fauci was quoted as saying.
(READ FULL REPORT HERE)

details.title: Initial results from COVID-19 sniffer dog trial promising
details.content: Preliminary experiments in the first major wave of infections earlier in the year suggested that the dogs can detect the novel coronavirus with close to 100 per cent accuracy, up to five days earlier than a PCR test. (READ FULL REPORT HERE)

details.title: Global update | Japan crosses one lakh COVID-19 cases, nine months after it reported the first one
details.content:
The country confirmed 808 new cases on Thursday, bringing the cumulative COVID-19 cases to 100,334, including 712 people who were on a cruise ship that was docked off a Japanese port earlier this year.
(READ FULL REPORT HERE)

details.title: Puducherry adds 149 new cases to its COVID-19 tally

Puducherry reports 149 new #COVID19 infections taking total cases to 34,908 out of which 3,739 are active patients.

Total of 592 deaths reported. pic.twitter.com/WwtkNOfhag

details.title: Satyendar Jain urges Delhiites to consider face masks like COVID-19 vaccine
details.content:
• As COVID-19 cases in Delhi continue to rise, Health Minister Satyendar Jain on Friday urged citizens to consider the face mask like a COVID-19 vaccine, especially in the upcoming festive season.
  • "When we had imposed the lockdown, cases did not go down. If 100 per cent of people wear masks, COVID-19 infection can be controlled to a certain extent. Benefits of wearing masks are just as many as those of a lockdown, if not more. Until there is a vaccine, masks should be considered vaccines," Jain said.
  • He further said that wearing masks would also help protect people from air pollution.

details.title: Tamil Nadu | Integrated Coronavirus ICU opened at Chennai hospital
details.content:
Chief Minister Edappadi K Palaniswami declared open an integrated, modern intensive care mobile unit for Covid treatment at KMC Hospital through video conference.

MEA was issuing 10 lakh passports per month before COVID-19: MoS Muraleedharan
details.content:
The Ministry of External Affairs was issuing approximately 10 lakh passports per month on an average before the COVID-19 pandemic struck, Minister of State for External Affairs V Muraleedharan said.
(READ FULL REPORT HERE)

details.title: Modi in Gujarat: 23 on-duty cops for PM's Kevadiya visit found COVID-19 positive
details.content:
During coronavirus tests of security personnel a day before Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit here, as many as 23 policemen were found infected with the disease, officials said on Friday. Over 5,000 police and State Reserve Police (SRP) personnel from different districts have been deployed in areas surrounding the Statue of Unity in the wake of Modi's visit to the monument near Kevadiya village in Narmada district on Friday and Saturday.

FULL REPORT HERE

details.title: Active COVID caseload falls below 6 lakh for 1st time in 3 months: Health Ministry
details.content: Active caseload of coronavirus infection in country dropped below 6 lakh for first time in nearly three months and comprises only 7.35 per cent of total cases: Union Health Ministry

details.title: Bombay HC lauds Mumbai Police for 'working against odds'
details.content: Bombay HC lauds Mumbai Police for 'working against odds', says police personnel are carrying out their duty under lot of pressure amid COVID19 pandemic and lockdown, and hence cooperation from public is required

details.title: Centre asks states to form committees for smooth COVID-19 vaccination drive
details.content:
The Health Ministry has sought constitution of committees at state and district levels which will review preparatory activities in terms of cold chain preparedness, operational planning, strategies for state-specific challenges in terms of geographical terrain and hard-to-reach areas, etc.

details.title: Karnataka Film Exhibitors Federation has decided to not reopen theatres till January-2021
details.content:

details.title: 3rd serosurvey in Odisha
details.content: According to the third round of serosurvey, antibodies against novel coronavirus is found in 50% people in Bhubaneswar. The survey was conducted between October 16-18, said ICMR, Bhubaneswar director Sanghamitra Pati.

details.title: Global Update from Taiwan: No locally transmitted cases in 200 days
details.content:
Cindy Wang and Samson Ellis of the Bloomberg reported that Taiwan had last recorded local case on April 12. "Taiwan is the only major country that has so far been able to keep community transmission of Covid eliminated," Peter Collignon, professor at the Australian National University Medical School.

FULL REPORT HERE

details.title: Passenger footfall to go up in Delhi buses
details.content: Delhi Lt governor approves govt's proposal to raise number of passengers in buses from 20 to full seating capacity amid pandemic. He further okayed resuming inter-state bus services with SOP in place: Official: Official

details.title: Tamil Nadu tally
details.content: Tamil Nadu reports 2,608 new COVID-19 cases, 38 deaths and 3,924 discharges today, as per the State Health Department. The total number of cases in the state is now at 7,22,011 including 6,87,388 discharges and 11,091 deaths. There are 23,532 active cases in the state.

details.title: Chennai's govt hospitals did dialysis free for 757 patients
details.content: The COVID-19 pandemic has posed many challenges for the healthcare system. Performing dialysis for COVID-19 patients with renal issues is one of them. Government hospitals in Chennai have conducted dialysis free of cost for a total of 757 COVID-19 patients since March. (READ MORE)

details.title: Lung infection in patients could clear up after six weeks
details.content: Doctors from the Tamil Nadu government-run post-Covid clinics attached to two medical college hospitals in Chennai said that a comparison of CT scan reports of the patients taken at admission and six weeks after discharge showed that infection in even patients with up to 75 per cent lung involvement resolved in that period, the lungs turning clear in many severely affected patients. (READ MORE)
